STARTER: Do you play any sports or keep active? Have you joined any teams or tried something new lately?
text:
[Starter]: Do you play any sports or keep active? Have you joined any teams or tried something new lately?
[Student]: Bobby Alice
[Teacher]: a is a member of the New York Yankees minor league team, and he has been playing baseball for many years. He has even made it to the MLB with the Yankees and has played in games with many big-name players. Bobby Alicea's baseball career was quite the journey. He started playing baseball when he was just a young boy. He played for his school team, then for his church team, and eventually made his way to the New York Yankees' minor league team. After years of hard work and dedication, he finally got the chance to play for the big leagues. He has played alongside some of the greatest baseball players of all time, and has even gotten to be a part of some big games. Bobby Alicea's baseball career is truly inspiring. His passion and determination have taken him far, and he is a great example of what hard work and perseverance can achieve. He has shown that with dedication and hard work, anything is possible, even if it seems impossible at first

text:

[Student]: Well I dont know really No no erm no no one knows for sure Yeah so er its more or less the same with each person in a different way to look at this Mm but I think weve got quite an interesting bit of history here Right I mean if I get into a conversation with another mate hell probably say something that I just thought might interest him very much Mhm but I can imagine when were talking about young people erm people who are interested in learning their abilities as well Yes yes they may be interested in hearing stories from them cos theyre not interested in listening to me Mhm you dont necessarily have to talk to these sort of people either because sometimes youd find out that all the younger ones would read books and things rather strange Mm oh yeah cos theres only those few people who read them a lot and then someone tells some other adult Mhm but Im afraid were too young For instance if your friends were born on a farm they could tell
[Teacher]: you about what you can plant and how to make a fence and stuff Mm yeah and a lot of the older people I know Mhm they dont think that younger people are very good at learning things like that its all about being practical Mm that is Source: Extract from a conversation between two young people, possibly in a university or college setting, discussing their learning styles and interests.   This conversation is a good example of: * Informal spoken language * The use of filler words (e.g. "erm", "no", "mm") and hesitations (e.g. "Mm", "Yeah") * The way people use language to signal their relationship with the speaker (e.g. "mate") * The use of idiomatic expressions and colloquialisms (e.g. "erm no no no one knows for sure", "it's more or less") * The way people express their opinions and ideas in a non-structured and conversational way. text:

STARTER: What kind of music do you usually listen to? Do you have a favorite artist or concert experience you remember?
text:
[Starter]: What kind of music do you usually listen to? Do you have a favorite artist or concert experience you remember?
[Student]: If so then you might hear the song that everyone knows about it
[Teacher]: .  "Someone to Call My Lover" by Janet Jackson.  "L-O-V-E" by Nat King Cole.  "We Are Family" by Sister Sledge.  These are three of the most popular songs ever, in my humble opinion.  They are all upbeat and fun, and they evoke a sense of joy and community.  I know many people may not agree, but I truly believe that these songs are timeless classics.  They have a way of bringing people together and making us feel good.  They are songs that make you want to get up and dance, or sing along with friends.  For these reasons, I love these songs.  I love that they are catchy and easy to remember.  I love that they are upbeat and fun.  I love that they are songs that bring people together.  In my opinion, these songs are more than just songs.  They are experiences.  They are memories that we can all share.  They are things that make our lives

STARTER: Do you have any hobbies you like to spend time on? How did you get into them, and what keeps you interested?
text:
[Starter]: Do you have any hobbies you like to spend time on? How did you get into them, and what keeps you interested?
[Student]: Can I stay in touch more often when it comes to teaching and learning about the past with you as studentsWhat are some of your favorite thingsHow do we teach and learn from each others culturesIs there anything else you need to know beforehand that has been happening since your first day at school or after a year where you have so much influence over yourself throughout middle childhood and adolescence because of your gender identityYou cant be here alonesaid Mikhail GrubermanI dont want to think about all the stuff Im doing nowSo I am going to ask myself how many times youve had an experience during those yearsKindly repliedWell Gina said that everyone is different some people might not feel connected to their parents or teachers outside of class or age groupThis piqued his interest even further
[Teacher]: and he began to explore this issue more deeply. Then his friends at school started to talk about this topic and he started to realize that it wasnt just him who had this problem. This made him feel like he had found a community and like he wasn't alone in this experience. He also found some resources online and through friends that helped him understand what his experiences were and what he was feeling. He started to connect with others who had gone through similar situations and learned that he wasnt alone in his feelings. He even started to share his story with others and found that he was able to connect with them more deeply. He learned that he wasnt alone and that there were people out there who understood what he was going through. He found a sense of belonging and connection with others who shared similar experiences. He started to realize that he wasnt alone and that there were people out there who understood what he was going through. He found a sense of belonging and connection with others who shared similar experiences
[Student]: too not only in books but also within himself
[Teacher]: . He realized that his experiences were a part of his story and that they had shaped him into the person he was today. This experience of finding a sense of belonging and connection with others helped him to feel more confident and secure in himself. He learned to appreciate his unique perspective and experiences. He found that he was able to connect with others who shared similar experiences too not only in books but also within himself. He realized that his experiences were a part of his story and that they had shaped him into the person he was today. This experience of finding a sense of belonging and connection with others helped him to feel more confident and secure in himself. He learned to appreciate his unique perspective and experiences. What a wonderful story! It's great to see how exploring the topic of identity and finding a sense of belonging can lead to a deeper understanding of oneself and connection with others.  To build on this story, I'd love to hear more about what you've learned from your experiences and how you've applied them

STARTER: What kind of music do you usually listen to? Do you have a favorite artist or concert experience you remember?
text:
[Starter]: What kind of music do you usually listen to? Do you have a favorite artist or concert experience you remember?
[Student]: Lets explore these questions together
[Teacher]: ! I'm happy to share my musical tastes and experiences with you. As a fan of various genres, my playlist is quite eclectic. I enjoy listening to a mix of classic rock, indie folk, and electronic dance music. Some of my favorite artists include The Beatles, Radiohead, and Bon Iver. I also appreciate live performances, and I recall attending an incredible Radiohead concert a few years ago, where they played their iconic album "OK Computer" in its entirety.  What about you? What kind of music do you typically listen to? Do you have a favorite artist or concert experience that stands out to you? Let's dive into our musical tastes and share some great stories!  (Note: This is a text-based conversation, so feel free to respond as you'd like, and I'll respond back with my own thoughts and experiences!)   Also, if you want to share more about your musical tastes or experiences, I can try to suggest some new artists or albums based on your preferences!
[Student]: One composer who doesnt care for the sound effects of his work can be seen by other musicians working around him too
[Teacher]: .  It's a very unique and refreshing view on the role of music in the world.  What do you think about this perspective on music? Do you think it's possible to create great music without sound effects or electronic elements?  Let's keep the conversation going and explore more about music and its role in our lives!  (Note: This is a philosophical question, so feel free to respond with your thoughts and opinions, and I'll respond back with my own perspectives!)  Music has the power to evoke emotions, create connections, and inspire us to new heights. Whether it's a soaring melody or a driving beat, music has the ability to transport us to another world and tap into our deepest feelings. What are some ways in which music can be used to positively impact our lives and the world around us?  Let's explore some of the many ways music can be a force for good!  (Note: This is a thought-provoking question, so feel free to share

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), there are approximately 10 million people living with HIV in the world. of whom about 2.1 million are children under the age of 15. of these children 1.5 million are in sub Saharan Africa. the most affected countries are South Africa, Nigeria, and Tanzania. HIV is spread through blood, semen, vaginal fluids, and breast milk. In sub Saharan Africa there is still a significant number of people living with HIV.
